questions.prompt: A circuit has b = 5 branches and n = 4 nodes (one datum). How many unknowns does the tableau system have?
questions.explanation: The tableau unknown vector x = [v_b; i_b; e] has 2b + (n−1) = 2(5) + 3 = 13 unknowns.

questions.prompt: Which equation set in the tableau formulation uses the reduced incidence matrix A directly?
questions.explanation: KCL is written as A · i_b = 0, directly using the reduced incidence matrix A.

questions.prompt: In the tableau matrix T, what appears in the block position corresponding to KVL equations and node voltage unknowns (e)?
questions.explanation: The KVL row of the tableau matrix is [I_b | 0 | −Aᵀ], so the block multiplying the node voltages e is −Aᵀ.

questions.prompt: How does tableau analysis handle an ideal voltage source V_s in branch k?
options: It replaces the branch with a short circuit
It writes v_k = V_s as the branch constitutive equation, leaving i_k as a free unknown
It converts the source to a Norton equivalent first
questions.correctAnswer: It writes v_k = V_s as the branch constitutive equation, leaving i_k as a free unknown
questions.explanation: Tableau analysis simply writes v_k = V_s as the branch equation. The current i_k is determined by the rest of the system through KCL/KVL — no special tricks are needed.

questions.prompt: For a CCCS with gain β controlling branch j, which row entries in the M_v and M_i sub-matrices are nonzero?
options: M_v has a 1 on the diagonal; M_i is all zeros
M_v is all zeros for this row; M_i has 1 on the diagonal and −β in column j
M_v has −β in column j; M_i has 1 on the diagonal
Both M_v and M_i have entries in column j
questions.correctAnswer: M_v is all zeros for this row; M_i has 1 on the diagonal and −β in column j
questions.explanation: A CCCS branch equation is i_k − β·i_j = 0. This involves only currents, so M_v row is all zeros, and the M_i row has +1 at column k (diagonal) and −β at column j.

questions.prompt: When is the tableau system T·x = u guaranteed to have a unique solution?
options: When the circuit has more nodes than branches
When the circuit contains no dependent sources
questions.explanation: The linear tableau system has a unique solution if and only if the tableau matrix T is nonsingular, i.e., det(T) ≠ 0.

questions.prompt: In a nonlinear tableau system F(x) = 0, which equation sets remain linear?
options: Only the branch constitutive equations remain linear
KCL and KVL remain linear; only branch equations may be nonlinear
questions.correctAnswer: KCL and KVL remain linear; only branch equations may be nonlinear
questions.explanation: KCL (A·i_b = 0) and KVL (v_b − Aᵀ·e = 0) are topological equations that depend only on the graph structure, not element physics. They are always linear. Only branch constitutive equations can be nonlinear.

questions.prompt: What iterative method is commonly used to solve the nonlinear tableau system F(x) = 0?
questions.explanation: Newton-Raphson iteration linearises the system around the current guess using the Jacobian J(x), solving J·Δx = −F(x) at each step. This is the standard approach used in SPICE.

questions.prompt: What is one key disadvantage of tableau analysis compared to nodal analysis?
options: The system size is larger: (2b + n − 1) vs (n − 1)
It requires nonlinear solvers even for linear circuits
questions.correctAnswer: The system size is larger: (2b + n − 1) vs (n − 1)
questions.explanation: The tableau system has 2b + n − 1 unknowns, while nodal analysis has only n − 1 unknowns. For large circuits, this size difference is significant, which is why Modified Nodal Analysis (MNA) is preferred in practice.

questions.prompt: An ideal transformer with turns ratio n coupling branches p and s contributes how many constitutive equations to the tableau system?
options: Two: v_p − n·v_s = 0 and n·i_p + i_s = 0
Three: one each for voltage, current, and power
None — it is handled purely by KCL/KVL
questions.correctAnswer: Two: v_p − n·v_s = 0 and n·i_p + i_s = 0
questions.explanation: An ideal transformer contributes two coupled branch constitutive equations: the voltage relation v_p = n·v_s and the current relation n·i_p + i_s = 0. Both are needed to fully specify the transformer behaviour.
